string_table.string: Closed captions. Press the spacebar to toggle captions on and off.
Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Welcome to the training on the new installation maintenance or NIM turnover process.

The purpose of this course is to provide you with skills to effectively complete the NIM process, including inspection and turnover, as a resource for performing your work.

This course has audio. Please adjust your computers speakers. If you would like to view navigation instructions for this course, click the link at the bottom of your screen.

At the completion of this lesson, you will be able to:

Describe the New Installation Maintenance Process or NIM, including inspection and turnover

Describe the roles of new installation and modernization operations and service and repair involved in NIM turnover

Utilize the automated NIM Tracker tool

Utilize the Gensuite Inspection Tool and Action Tracking System

Implement best practices of a clean hand off

NIM is defined as new installation maintenance, and it involves activities to turnover a newly installed or modernized unit from construction to our service department.

Click the blue circled steps in the process diagram with your mouse to learn more about each.

· Once the project is booked, communication begins. Sales, operations, and service are all notified and aware of the new project from the beginning.

· The unit is tracked throughout the entire process in the NIM tracker, an automated tool that can be used by all departments to track the projects progress.

· Service sales is notified when the inspection is scheduled so they can setup the NIM contract. This facilitates the NIM contract being available in the system prior to turnover.

· As schedules are adjusted they are communicated between construction, modernization and service operations. This keeps the service department informed of upcoming turnovers. Both the adjuster and service mechanic complete the checklist in Gensuite together and any deficiencies are corrected by both of them.

· Final repairs are assessed and completed in a timely manner through the collaboration of NI/MOD operations and service.

· Final acceptance is signed and delivered to the branch. The final acceptance packet is sent to service to update the NIM contract with the final details.

The NIM team turnover begins during the inspection and turnover phase of the new installation and modernization processes and continues through the project closeout phase.

Inspection and turnover is when the unit is ready for the final inspection before being turned over to the customer. If the unit is serviced by our service department, the NIM team turnover marks the transition of the equipment to service.

During the NIM process, office personnel ensure all proper forms are submitted and the Pre-NIM contract is setup.

The NIM team turnover is scheduled with the adjuster and service operations manager who then identifies and schedules the service mechanic.

Field personnel ensure equipment meets installation standards, completes the inspection along with the service technician and together they fix any unit deficiencies.

Click next to learn more about the roles that the office and the field have during the NIM process.

Several different roles play an active part in the NIM team turnover process. Some roles may overlap depending on the individual branch.

Click the roles below to learn more about each.

What are the benefits of the new NIM process?

The NIM process promotes complete transparency of upcoming turnovers across multiple lines of business.

Enhances the customer experience due to proactive setup to identify customer and location at point of turnover and increases communication

Enables the service mechanic to be aware of the unit, location and customer needs early in the process.

Increases collaboration between departments, which improves the customer experience and retains or impacts the securing of service contracts.

The NIM Process crosses multiple lines of business. A procedure has been created for the NIM process that also affects many other existing procedures.

Access the procedure New Installation Maintenance Process to learn more. It addresses procedures for both new installation and modernization operations, service sales and service operations. It links to other existing procedures and highlights their changes. For example, you will see the highlighted section in the NIM Process procedure is the change within the Conducting a Weekly Branch Meeting procedure. If you click the Conducting Weekly Branch Meeting procedure you may open it to see the entire procedure. You may find the same change within the procedure just opened.

You can access this and other pertinent procedures in the resources section at the top right of your training.

Operations, sales and service should communicate early and often to ensure transparency throughout the process.

Field employees should conduct the final inspection together with the service mechanic to ensure a smooth transition.

Proper tracking and inspection tools should be used to document the units progress throughout the process, which will be discussed in the following module.
Click Next to answer the following questions to test how much youve learned!

The NIM Turnover Tracker is used to document the units progress from booking to service. All parties involved in the NIM process can access the Turnover Tracker to view and update progress. To access the NIM Turnover Tracker, you will need a log in to the SharePoint site where it is housed. This is the same as the SharePoint Business Performance Review site.

If you do not have access to the BPR SharePoint site, you will be prompted to enter the reason you need access to the site. Enter a brief reason and click submit. You will be notified through email once access is granted. Your log in is your network ID and password. Once in the BPR site, hover over your region and select your district to go to the home page.

Once youre in the site, click NIM at the bottom right, then click NIM Tracker. We will discuss the use of the NIM Turnover Tracker in this lesson.

Here you will see the dashboard for the NIM Turnover Tracking tool. You may filter by region, district, branch, line of business or completed status. Please note, you will only be able to view the region, district and branches that are assigned to you.

You may also sort by column headers by clicking the drop down on each column header.

The first five columns on the left pre-populate information from Oracle. When populating the adjusters name, edit the column to add the mechanics name and the inspection checklist date, if the checklist is completed together.

The eight columns to the right are manual entry that need to be filled in. Click submit at the top right to commit the information entered to the database. Manual entries can be edited and resubmitted.

The GS Address column is used to paste the Gensuite link into the tracker. Once submitted this will populate the link in the Link column to be able to update Gensuite while reviewing the tracker.

Check the completed column once the NIM Turnover is completed. You may use the completed drop-down menu and a filter value of no to show only active units.

The filtered view can be exported to excel. But please note changes to the excel, exported document do not update the information in the NIM Turnover Tracker.
Now its your turn to practice! Click on the blue button below to access the Try It UPKs on the NIM Turnover Tracker and Linking Gensuite to the NIM Turnover Tracker.
Click Next to answer the following questions to test how much youve learned!

In this course, you learned how to:

Describe the NIM Process, including inspection and turnover

Describe the roles of New Installation and Modernization Operations and Service and Repair involved in NIM Turnover

Utilize the automated NIM Tracker tool

Utilize the Gensuite Inspection Tool and Action tracking System

Implement best practices of a clean hand off

Lets see what youve learned!

Answer the following questions in the graded final quiz. 80% is a passing score.
Thank you for completing this training. To close the course, click the X to close this Internet window.

Gensuite is a desktop and mobile application that supports quality and continuous improvement at thyssenkrupp Elevator through online tools such as the Elevator Inspection Tool, Quality Concern Reporting and Action Tracking System. Two of these applications are used in the NIM process, the Inspection Tool and the Action Tracking System, which we will review briefly together today.

To obtain access to Gensuite:

Attend a Gensuite training session

Email Karen Tolson, the Senior Director of Quality Systems at karen.tolson@thyssenkrupp.com

Compose an email stating:

Your name and title

Subject line should be Gensuite Access

When you completed training and with whom.

Which applications within Gensuite you need access to, i.e. Action Tracking System and Inspection Tool
Lets take a look at the inspection tool. Click on the inspection tool menu item now to view it.

Once in the inspection tool, you will see the dashboard where you can search for previous inspections or start a new one. To start a new inspection, click Inspect Now at the top of the screen. Then choose which Elevator Turnover Checklist you need from the drop-down menu. As you can see, the Modernization checklist for oildraulic and traction, along with the New Installation checklists for oildraulic and traction are available. Once you make your selection, click launch inspection. The identifier needs to be populated as the job number. The format for the identifier is three letters plus three numbers. The inspection type should be NIM Elevator, which is under Service header. The name of the supporting inspector needs to be populated in the comments box. The dates populate for you. Please do not change the dates from the default at this time.

Click through the numbered tabs at the top to answer the inspection checklist questions. The system defaults to under evaluation, but you may choose yes to indicate that the part is working properly, or you may choose no to indicate that a deficiency has been identified or choose not applicable. Once you click through all of the tabs and answer all of the questions, click submit at the top right to submit your inspection checklist.

Most field employees complete the inspection through a mobile application on their phones. Office employees should have an understanding of what the mobile app looks like. Click the blue button at the bottom of your screen to view an example.

The mobile app is similar to the desktop tool and easy to use. Field employees predominantly complete the Elevator Inspection Checklist through the mobile app. For more information on using the mobile app, view the Gensuite mobile app training document in the resources section of this module.

As you click through each tab answering questions, sometimes you will respond no and be required to enter further information. Please enter a brief description and the corrective action that took place or will take place. Once you have completed the checklist and clicked submit, you will be asked to export any findings to the Action Tracking System. Click export.

Please note that the application will not allow you to submit your Inspection Checklist without completing all the questions. The Action Name should be populated with the job name. Then you will need to indicate the responsible party and the required date. The verification is helpful, but not required to be completed.

Your submissions will then go into the Action Tracking System. Once your actions are submitted, you will receive an email to your inbox. Click next to see an example of the email.

Once you export your findings, you will receive an email from Gensuite where you may access the Action Tracking System from the email to correct and close your findings. You may click the Finding ID number or the edit link at the bottom to edit your findings. You will continue to receive emails from Gensuite until the finding is closed.

Click the Edit this Action Finding link at the bottom now to enter the Action Tracking System.

Once you have submitted your inspection, you will see that you have an item in the Action Tracking System that needs to be followed up on. Click the Action Tracking System to see your actions to complete.

Click Action Tracking System now.

In the Action Tracking System, you will see your status summary at the bottom with your open findings and year to date findings. You may click on the blue, linked numbers to view your findings and close them.

Click the hyperlinked numbers in the gold box now.

Once you expand your status summary, you will be able to view your closure due date, the action name and number with a brief description, building information, corrective action, responsible person, status and other pertinent information.

If you click on the responsible person link, it will allow you to write an email to the responsible person through Gensuite. If you click on the open status link, it will allow you to edit the finding.
Click Next to answer the following questions to test how much youve learned!

The objective behind the NIM process is to provide a better customer experience through transparency and communication. It is designed to increase customer satisfaction and quality through better collaboration between sales, operations and service. Ultimately, this will provide a smoother transition for both our internal and external customers.

The NIM process encourages:

Branch manager ownership and accountability

Early forecasting of jobs to service

Collaboration during the inspection between the adjuster and service mechanic with one checklist and proactive troubleshooting

Deficiencies corrected upstream before they reach the customer

15 day service inspection period eliminated

Contract setup prior to final acceptance

All inspections complete prior to final customer acceptance

Automated tracking tool used by all departments

For more information, you may consult the standard operating procedure located in the Resources section of this training module.
